utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""VALLEY GIRL"")
(Singing) He goes like bag your face, I'm sure.
(Singing) Valley girl.
She's a valley girl.
Valley girl.
She's a valley girl.
Therefore, I, Sheila Dixon, mayor of the city of Baltimore, do hereby proclaim August 9, 2007 as Frank Zappa Day in Baltimore and do urge all citizens to join in this celebration.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Michele Norris.
On September 10th, it was an ordinary day.
I was going into the office.
Right, of course.
We have to remember this is not a national election.
It's 50 individual elections, plus the District of Columbia.
But a national lead again is interesting to see that, you know, one party in Newsweek headed by 50 points, LA Times headed by 12 points.
You'd expect that Barack Obama to get a bump out of having won the Democratic nomination.
John McCain has not been in the news of late, and many of the times he has made news, it's not been good news, like the Charlie Black statement we can talk about later.
But the polls do show him with a double-digit lead.
But again, you know, the campaign hasn't really started.
I don't think people are really focused, yet.
I think once Labor Day comes it will be very interesting to see what those polls show.
In previous elections, we've talked about the gender gap or the security gap.
And boy, the first phrase of this general election campaign, the LA Times poll talked about a passion gap.
Well - but that's where you certainly have the McCain people.

I mean, we always talked about whether the Hillary people will come over to Barack Obama in November, and we saw a lot of polls in the later primary stage showing that many are reluctant to do so in Pennsylvania, Ohio, West Virginia and Indiana.
Some 30 percent of Hillary's supporters said they would be reluctant to support Obama.
I suspect that as we get closer to November that will change, but there is a passion gap, as you say, with McCain supporters.
A lot of conservatives still say that he is not the real-deal, they're weary about him, and they're looking at other options for November.
And we have a couple of callers who think they know the answer to our trivia question.
Which is, again, who was the last presidential candidate to win more states, but lose the presidency?
And let's see if we can go to George, and George is with us from Tallahassee in Florida.
Good afternoon, Neal and Ken.
Was it Richard Nixon in 1960?
Well, Richard Nixon did win 26 states more than John F.
Kennedy.
John F.
Kennedy won 23 states, but that was not the most recent.
Actually, I think it's only twice it's happened.
Nixon and Kennedy was one of them, but there was one, more recent.
OK.
OK, George, thanks for the call.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Certainly.
All right.
Let's see if we can get...
You know how they count in Florida, anyway.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's go to Chris, and Chris is with us in Traverse City, in Michigan.
Oh yeah, my guess was Nixon, also.
But then I would guess, you know, if you're going by popular vote, it was Gore.
So...
Now, we're going for states.
Number of states.
You're going by states.
Carter?
Well, that's correct.
Gerald Ford in 1976, Gerald Ford won 27 states.
Jimmy Carter won 23 and the District of Columbia, but Carter had the most popular - most electoral votes, and won the election.
Well, you got two bites of the apple, Chris, and right the second time.
So, you get our no prize today.
(Soundbite of applause)
Wonderful.
Thanks very much for the call.
Great.
So, anyway, let's get back to politics, and you mentioned Charlie Black who mentioned in an interview, I think, with - was it Fortune Magazine?
Fortune Magazine, yes.
That if there's a terrorist attack it would help his candidate.
His words were it certainly would be a big advantage, and a lot of people recoiled, as they should.
It was a horrific thing to say or think about.
John McCain distanced himself completely from it, but I think a lot of people also feel that there's some truth to it.
Or let me put it this way.

If George Bush does something - if President Bush does something that precipitates some kind of attack, then the Obama campaign could say, justifiably I think, that President Bush has not made us safe.

If there's an attack from some extremist, and you know - I mean, John Kerry said in 2004 that Osama bin Laden, when he released a tape in late October, that really helped seal his fate in the 2004 election against President Bush.

But what about the argument that the Obama camp, and a lot of other Democrats, and they didn't need more than the Democrats, that well they're not making it safer and they're - the Republican Party is - the Republicans in power have, you know, campaigned on the idea that they've prevented attacks.

Right, exactly, and that's why both sides - I mean, it's too easy to say that, yes, it helps McCain, just like I think most Democrats feel that if gas goes up to five dollars a gallon, which seems to be headed towards that, that has to help the Democratic Party.
Not that they're...
Not that they're rooting for it.
Exactly, and it almost sounded like Charlie Black - and, of course, Charlie Black was not rooting for that.
But it almost seemed like he was saying this would be a great benefit to us.
Forget about the, you know, the casualties and the terrible things that could happen as a result of that.
And let me ask also about a primary that was held yesterday in the state of Utah, where Congressman Chris Cannon lost to a more conservative rival.
Chris Cannon is perhaps one of the most - certainly, not perhaps - one of the most conservative members of congress.

He's from Utah, first elected in 1966, very, very conservative, but he supports President Bush's decision on immigration, in to allowing illegal immigrants to get this guest-worker program to help them find jobs.
And the last two times, the two previous times, when Cannon ran, he was challenged in the primary by a far more conservative candidate.
He barely won this time.
He didn't win a former chief of staff to the governor there.
Jason Chaffetz was nominated yesterday, saying that Cannon did not represent Republican values.
OK.
To me, he just confirmed what he's all about.
He talks out of both sides of his mouth.
So you do care that he broke his promise?
And interesting, it was on the issue of immigration, which John McCain seems to be out of step with much of his party.

Indeed, there was a report that he had a closed door meeting with some Latinos in Chicago this week, and told them, behind closed doors, that look, I'm not going to press this in the campaign, but I'm still committed to comprehensive immigration reform.
And Tom Tancredo, the retiring Republican congressman from Colorado, got wind of it, and said this is just a betrayal.
So obviously that's the dilemma that John McCain has.
He feels that obviously reaching out to Hispanics, Latinos, he can open up the chances for Republicans to get more votes.
But at the same time, conservatives, as we saw in Utah's third district, are very, very wary, and angry about this kind of politics.

And we're going to be focusing this week, and when we come back, we want listener calls on the question of do you care that Barack Obama broke his promise to take public financing during the general election phase of the campaign, and how is it going to change the campaign?

But as you look at this, this has got to be an interesting calculation for somebody who said he would very aggressively pursue an agreement with a candidate McCain to make sure that they both accepted public financing.
That's true, but at the same time, I mean, a lot of people argue, make the case, that having 300, perhaps 500, million dollars at his disposal, how do you turn that down?
There are a lot of good government types, and we'll probably hear from some good government types today, who feel that this is a betrayal of trust.
Every candidate since the institutions - since Watergate, since these reforms were...
